headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. That comment was made to help explain how you take a negative 7% volume number, which I think that the audience may pay too much attention to, and generate growth in the revenue number of our overall Commercial book of business, which is
componenttext: I don't think so. That comment was made to help explain how you take a negative 7% volume number, which I think that the audience may pay too much attention to, and generate growth in the revenue number of our overall Commercial book of business, which is the important statistic that drives earnings ultimately, and that is one component of it. It can be due to many things, including growth or relative lack of growth in different health plans.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Brendan Strong from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Brendan Strong from Barclays Capital.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: When we look at the commercial trends, I mean, they are very similar to what they were in the first quarter. So really no big change here. I guess, as you think about the rest of the year, I mean, do you think if the unemployment rates stays similar to wh
componenttext: When we look at the commercial trends, I mean, they are very similar to what they were in the first quarter. So really no big change here. I guess, as you think about the rest of the year, I mean, do you think if the unemployment rates stays similar to where we're at today, do you think we'll be looking at similar declines in commercial trends for the rest of the year?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It would be speculative to answer the question directly, but this is driven by the things that we've talked about. So employment is key. It creates more people that could potentially be covered under commercial insurance. You've got the shifts among payer
componenttext: It would be speculative to answer the question directly, but this is driven by the things that we've talked about. So employment is key. It creates more people that could potentially be covered under commercial insurance. You've got the shifts among payers that's very important in driving the revenue number. And you've got this issue with elective procedures, most importantly OB. And I think what we're trying to do is highlight a more important economic trend, which is very -- again similar to the first quarter, the volumes that we've been losing the most that are contributing to those volume loss numbers are the ones with the least value associated with them. And that is in part how we've been able to continue to grow revenues even in the face of those weak volume numbers.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I would just add that certainly, we think our actions will help drive commercial volumes in the future. And as you say, the economy improving will drive commercial volumes more favorably in the future. But having said that for the sake of conservatism, th
componenttext: I would just add that certainly, we think our actions will help drive commercial volumes in the future. And as you say, the economy improving will drive commercial volumes more favorably in the future. But having said that for the sake of conservatism, the middle of our range in the outlook presumes that the trends through the first half are sustained through the year. So for purposes of the outlook, we have presumed that the economy does not turn and that there's no other windfall that would change the current trend. But obviously, we're working to operate in a different direction and create growth.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I don't know if there's any other color you guys can provide on the Medicare side as well; that's part of the business that you think would be kind of stable. But theres some declines there on the admission side, too. So I presume part of tha
componenttext: And then, I don't know if there's any other color you guys can provide on the Medicare side as well; that's part of the business that you think would be kind of stable. But theres some declines there on the admission side, too. So I presume part of thats because of some procedures being delayed, because of co-pays possibly. But any color around that?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, do you want to add some color on that?
componenttext: Steve, do you want to add some color on that?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Brendan, I think you're right. I think we are beginning to see some increase in elective surgeries of Medicare patients. That too has been impacted by the downturn in the general economy. But for example, orthopedic surgery in Medicare was up 1% in
componenttext: Sure. Brendan, I think you're right. I think we are beginning to see some increase in elective surgeries of Medicare patients. That too has been impacted by the downturn in the general economy. But for example, orthopedic surgery in Medicare was up 1% in the quarter compared to the same quarter prior year. So I think we're beginning to see that. But it's only a small glimmer at this point.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Gary Lieberman from Wells Fargo.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping that maybe you could talk a little bit about what you're continuing to do in terms of attracting physicians and maybe some other measures that you're taking to try to reverse the trend or at least ameliorate the trend on a commercial managed
componenttext: I was hoping that maybe you could talk a little bit about what you're continuing to do in terms of attracting physicians and maybe some other measures that you're taking to try to reverse the trend or at least ameliorate the trend on a commercial managed care admission front?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, we've been doing a lot. And Stephen, you want to answer that?
componenttext: Gary, we've been doing a lot. And Stephen, you want to answer that?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, the number for the quarter, 245 active staff net of attrition added to staff, that's consistent with the forecast we made at the previous quarter for the year. But above and beyond that, we've accelerated our physician alignment activities a
componenttext: First of all, the number for the quarter, 245 active staff net of attrition added to staff, that's consistent with the forecast we made at the previous quarter for the year. But above and beyond that, we've accelerated our physician alignment activities and each of our hospitals now has a customized physician alignment plan. And we've added a number of tactics to that particular plan, including the roll-out of office-based Health Information Technology through our joint venture partner, Med3000. We are tying our doctors more closely to our facilities through this HIT set of products and that will make a difference longer term. Additionally, we are reactivating a number of organizations that we had 10 or 12 years ago that are called Physician Hospital Organizations. These are entities that are jointly owned by physicians and hospitals, and allow for contracting on a single signature, whether it be with a commercial payer or a governmental payer. So we're doing a number of things, Gary, to increase our physician alignment that should translate into growing our volumes, especially our commercial volume.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of focus this quarter on one particular acquisition that you guys indicated you were looking at. Could you just bring us up to speed on what your current thoughts are in terms of potential acquisitions? And kind of where you might be looking
componenttext: There's a lot of focus this quarter on one particular acquisition that you guys indicated you were looking at. Could you just bring us up to speed on what your current thoughts are in terms of potential acquisitions? And kind of where you might be looking and where you might not be looking?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think first of all, it's important to understand we don't need to make acquisitions to meet our goals. So we believe we continue to have significant margin upside in the current portfolio, and we spent a lot of time in June and July in Investor Relation
componenttext: I think first of all, it's important to understand we don't need to make acquisitions to meet our goals. So we believe we continue to have significant margin upside in the current portfolio, and we spent a lot of time in June and July in Investor Relations activities talking to people about those sources of margin expansion. We are actively pursuing acquisitions in the outpatient imaging space. These are small dollars, but they're very accretive and they generate very high IR. I'd like to make acquisitions in our Service business in order to expand our scale, but those tend to be very expensive and they're hard to find the right fit. And then on acute acquisitions, it does seem as though the supply side of that market is increasing very steadily, but we're going to continue to be very careful in that area looking for selective acquisitions where we would have a high degree of confidence in generating returns that would be well above our cost of capital. And other than that, I really can't be more specific. Itll be very situation dependent.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Doug Simpson from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Doug Simpson from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Trevor, could you just talk a little bit -- just stepping back, if we look at the enterprise increase that the industrys seeing, they're above GDP and then we've got this dynamic where we're seeing a sluggish commercial utilization. Is there a broader
componenttext: Trevor, could you just talk a little bit -- just stepping back, if we look at the enterprise increase that the industrys seeing, they're above GDP and then we've got this dynamic where we're seeing a sluggish commercial utilization. Is there a broader sort of question, looking out two years, do you foresee any change in strategy relative to pricing to try to get volumes back up just as sort of an affordability issue or is it more just when the economy rebounds, we should get some pickup from that? Can you separate the two?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a very tough question because we have examined this question quite extensively here. I think there are several ways to approach it. So first of all, I think we are still in an environment where there is not a direct correlation between pricing and vo
componenttext: It's a very tough question because we have examined this question quite extensively here. I think there are several ways to approach it. So first of all, I think we are still in an environment where there is not a direct correlation between pricing and volume. There just doesn't seem to be any evidence of that. I think that volume is driven by all of the strategies that we outlined about physician alignment and about competitive positioning within markets and the local economies. And again, you get into these micro localities where it really, the particular employment position in a very small market makes a difference. I think going forward, is in terms of changing strategies, we have employed for some time a differentiating strategy on clinical quality. We thought that, that would generate differentiated volumes and there were quarters when it appeared to be doing so. But I'm not sure you can make a blanket statement on that. I think that as transparency increases and as health plans focus more on delivering value to their customers, the quality differentiation will have to play an important part. I want to make sure that even though we have generated strong increases in per unit revenues over the past several years, we still believe that our pricing positions us very effectively in terms of delivering value in the markets. Rarely are we the high-priced provider in a market. That position is usually held by a large not-for-profit system in a particular market. And then in terms of dealing with us from a health plan perspective, we have a very efficient revenue cycle, a very efficient back office, we have very few disputes with the payers. And so we try to point out to them that as they look at the overall cost of doing business with providers, we tend to be positioned very effectively. I think those strategies will continue to be legitimate and valuable for the foreseeable future. When you get into several years from now into tiering of networks and more restrictive networks and so forth, I think we're also well positioned for that. And that is where you may begin to see opportunities to link price and volume. But I don't think the industrys just not there today.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: As you look back to prior slowdowns, either regionally or nationally, any sense of timing with utilization slowdowns and relative to downturns in the economy, how long that may take to play out in terms of the lag effect?
componenttext: As you look back to prior slowdowns, either regionally or nationally, any sense of timing with utilization slowdowns and relative to downturns in the economy, how long that may take to play out in terms of the lag effect?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's really hard. We haven't seen one this long. And I don't think anybody, Ive talked to all sorts of people in the industry; I don't think anyone has seen one this widespread or this pervasive.
componenttext: It's really hard. We haven't seen one this long. And I don't think anybody, Ive talked to all sorts of people in the industry; I don't think anyone has seen one this widespread or this pervasive.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have your next question from the line of Sheryl Skolnick from CRT Capital Group.
componenttext: And you have your next question from the line of Sheryl Skolnick from CRT Capital Group.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I want to probe on the change in acuity a little bit more if I could. And perhaps if you look at those remaining, for lack of a better word, heads in the beds, x the OB/GYN, x the respiratory/flu, and you look at your ER visits, is there any link or any i
componenttext: I want to probe on the change in acuity a little bit more if I could. And perhaps if you look at those remaining, for lack of a better word, heads in the beds, x the OB/GYN, x the respiratory/flu, and you look at your ER visits, is there any link or any indication that patients being admitted for treatment or surgery through the ER are of higher acuity today than they were a year ago?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Sheryl, I think we have a couple of data points that would tend to suggest that the patients are more acute that are being admitted. If you look at the commercial managed care patients that get admitted through our ER and compare the Q2 '10 results to Q2
componenttext: Sheryl, I think we have a couple of data points that would tend to suggest that the patients are more acute that are being admitted. If you look at the commercial managed care patients that get admitted through our ER and compare the Q2 '10 results to Q2 '09, the case mix index is 3% higher than it was in '09. So it would suggest that the commercial patients coming in through the ER are indeed sicker than they were a year ago. The other point is that Trevor mentioned that our overall ED admissions are flat compared to the same quarter prior year. The fact that we had 2,000 fewer visits for influenza would in fact increase the overall case mix index of patients we're seeing in the ED and, therefore, those admitted would be higher acuity. So I think those two data points reinforce the observation that our ED is admitting sicker patients than it was a year ago.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, because I'm wondering if we're seeing the showing up later and sicker effect of delaying whats elective, let it become urgent, then let it become emergency and whether that might be the very early stages of an interesting trend that could further
componenttext: Yes, because I'm wondering if we're seeing the showing up later and sicker effect of delaying whats elective, let it become urgent, then let it become emergency and whether that might be the very early stages of an interesting trend that could further offset some of the headwinds in commercial managed care.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly, we have been concerned about that from a theoretical point of view. It's a little early to call that. But that's the sort of activity we would expect to escalate if, in fact, that bolus of pent-up demand is coming forward, we would see it
componenttext: Well, certainly, we have been concerned about that from a theoretical point of view. It's a little early to call that. But that's the sort of activity we would expect to escalate if, in fact, that bolus of pent-up demand is coming forward, we would see it through the EDs as you suggested.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And I can count on you all to have that data at your fingertips. As then as a follow-up, Trevor, the refinancing and reduction of debt that you're doing is I think timely and interesting, as well as the -- and a good thing, as well as looking at the credi
componenttext: And I can count on you all to have that data at your fingertips. As then as a follow-up, Trevor, the refinancing and reduction of debt that you're doing is I think timely and interesting, as well as the -- and a good thing, as well as looking at the credit facility but you intrigued me with one of your comments, which is having the flexibility to do share repurchases. Rather than read anything into that, could you share with us your thoughts on once you have that flexibility, whether or not you would be inclined to do it, assuming for example you had that flexibility today?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: After intriguing you with that comment, I went on to say that I wouldn't say anything more about those kinds of activities at this time, because it would be dependent on the situation at the time after we have gained that flexibility. The situation meanin
componenttext: After intriguing you with that comment, I went on to say that I wouldn't say anything more about those kinds of activities at this time, because it would be dependent on the situation at the time after we have gained that flexibility. The situation meaning what are the market conditions, whats our outlook, what opportunities have we had to deploy the capital and what at that time is the best use of capital?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: You have the next question from the line of Darren Lehrich from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: You have the next question from the line of Darren Lehrich from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to go back to the M&A strategy question that was asked previously. I think Trevor, you've laid out maybe three things that are on the table that you're really kind of focusing on, imaging some things in the services side of the busin
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to go back to the M&A strategy question that was asked previously. I think Trevor, you've laid out maybe three things that are on the table that you're really kind of focusing on, imaging some things in the services side of the business. I guess that would be more revenue-cycle oriented and then selectively acute care. I guess just given what's unfolded over the last three to four months, is there anything that youve brought up to your board that you would firmly say is off the table from here? Can you just help us think a little bit more clearly about capital deployment on the acquisition side and whether you've made any firm decisions about what's off the table?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I don't really have anything to add to what I said earlier. And no, I don't think anything is particularly off the table. But by our actions, I think you can gain insights into what we're thinking.
componenttext: I don't really have anything to add to what I said earlier. And no, I don't think anything is particularly off the table. But by our actions, I think you can gain insights into what we're thinking.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And you mentioned that the medical office building sale was something you're still working through. Can you just give us an update about that and any other asset sales that might be contemplated from here?
componenttext: And you mentioned that the medical office building sale was something you're still working through. Can you just give us an update about that and any other asset sales that might be contemplated from here?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's been a long process, but we have continued to look to sell medical office buildings. You may recall in the prior call, I commented that rather than trying to sell them all in one large transaction, we've broken them up into smaller transactions by ma
componenttext: It's been a long process, but we have continued to look to sell medical office buildings. You may recall in the prior call, I commented that rather than trying to sell them all in one large transaction, we've broken them up into smaller transactions by market or by region in order to make financing more readily available for purchasers. And we presently do have a number of them under contract. But having said that, our real estate contract isn't done until it closes, and so it's premature to say that there is definitively any additional cash coming in. But we're certainly hopeful that we will have at least some of them get to the point of close this year. If not this year, then into next year.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And is there a range of either numbers of assets, square footage thats sort of on the block? Can you just help size what you're working on at this point?
componenttext: And is there a range of either numbers of assets, square footage thats sort of on the block? Can you just help size what you're working on at this point?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The total opportunity that remains in front of us for those that we're still trying to market, I'd put it in the range of $100 million. But once again, there can be no assurance that we will ultimately close on all those or that's the amount that would be
componenttext: The total opportunity that remains in front of us for those that we're still trying to market, I'd put it in the range of $100 million. But once again, there can be no assurance that we will ultimately close on all those or that's the amount that would be received. But just for the sake of sizing what the opportunity is, that's a reasonable number to work with.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And the EBITDA loss relative to that $100 million would be what?
componenttext: And the EBITDA loss relative to that $100 million would be what?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It's nominal. As we said before, these are properties which don't generate a lot of earnings for us. We think that quite frankly another owner that's a professional real estate manager will be able to operate them more efficiently, number one. And secondl
componenttext: It's nominal. As we said before, these are properties which don't generate a lot of earnings for us. We think that quite frankly another owner that's a professional real estate manager will be able to operate them more efficiently, number one. And secondly, to the benefit of our physician tenants. And so, it makes sense for these to change hands in just about all respects.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice from Susquehanna.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of A.J. Rice from Susquehanna.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just give us your update in -- if there is any update on thoughts on things like the managed care contracting outlook for next year? Your thoughts on how the FMAP extension and the COBRA state of play, those payer dynamics, who will get into the f
componenttext: Can you just give us your update in -- if there is any update on thoughts on things like the managed care contracting outlook for next year? Your thoughts on how the FMAP extension and the COBRA state of play, those payer dynamics, who will get into the forward year  whats your thinking on those at this point?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I would like to thank you on the issues of COBRA and FMAP for injecting some rational thought into the hysteria that seems to surround those topics. I guess, I'll take FMAP first. I don't think I'm telling anybody on the call something they don't already
componenttext: I would like to thank you on the issues of COBRA and FMAP for injecting some rational thought into the hysteria that seems to surround those topics. I guess, I'll take FMAP first. I don't think I'm telling anybody on the call something they don't already know. But the Senate appears to be willing to continue to work on this. I can understand why they would not have necessarily wanted to pass something before the recess, but it's important to the governors. We have tried to estimate what an effect on us would be if the FMAP incremental money were not continued, and it hit directly and only to the Medicaid budget of every state and if we proportionately were hit directly. So I don't if you should call that a worst-case analysis. But it's a direct flow through directly to us of eliminating those funds and the total would be what, Biggs?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It would be just under $70 million. But Ill emphasize, that is kind of a worst-case number, because I dont think
componenttext: It would be just under $70 million. But Ill emphasize, that is kind of a worst-case number, because I dont think

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Its sort of inconceivable that it would actually work that way. But seems to me that people are sort of pricing in fears that are far greater than that. On COBRA
componenttext: Its sort of inconceivable that it would actually work that way. But seems to me that people are sort of pricing in fears that are far greater than that. On COBRA

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I should point out, that's the annual number.
componenttext: I should point out, that's the annual number.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, annual numbers. So in COBRA, it's been very difficult for us, as we've said repeatedly for a long time, to identify which patients are affected by that and so forth. And it may be that we're seeing the results of that COBRA roll-off now, I don't know
componenttext: Yes, annual numbers. So in COBRA, it's been very difficult for us, as we've said repeatedly for a long time, to identify which patients are affected by that and so forth. And it may be that we're seeing the results of that COBRA roll-off now, I don't know. But I still think that ones just totally amorphous. And then with respect to the pricing environment, its, obviously, never easy. But the fact that we are essentially done for 2010 and 75% contracted for '11 and into the mid-30s in terms of percentage of our Managed Care business done for 2012, gives us an extraordinary amount of visibility into what we think pricing trends are into 2011 and 2012, and it's obviously considered in the comments that we've made today.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just maybe a follow-up on that. One thing that I encounter, I guess, and I'd be interested in your perspective on it, is the sustainability of the cost trends. Obviously, in the face of the weak commercial volumes and the other dynamics around th
componenttext: And then just maybe a follow-up on that. One thing that I encounter, I guess, and I'd be interested in your perspective on it, is the sustainability of the cost trends. Obviously, in the face of the weak commercial volumes and the other dynamics around this economic downturn, you've been able to have very good cost controls on key items like labor and supplies. But I think theres sort of this concern that if these payer pressures continue to exert themselves out there, at some point you sort of hit a wall on that cost savings. I guess I'm trying to get my arms around, I wonder if you've thought about the issue of whether -- does all of this go hand-in-hand, that the cost opportunities youre realizing are hand-in-hand with some of the things that are driving the commercial volume pressures, for example? Or do you see a point in time where some of the sustainability of some of these things gets called into question?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: As you face a declining volume environment, it does get more difficult to continue to reduce staffing because you run into certain core and minimum staffing. But that's why we really sometime ago turned our attention to more creative approaches to cost re
componenttext: As you face a declining volume environment, it does get more difficult to continue to reduce staffing because you run into certain core and minimum staffing. But that's why we really sometime ago turned our attention to more creative approaches to cost reduction, such as those that are part of the Medicare performance initiative. And that really gets to a whole different range of cost opportunities in the utilization of supplies and length of stay and even the clinical practice of medicine. That together with the investments we're making in technology should open up new opportunities for us in cost management beyond the traditional levers that were largely oriented towards labor. And again, I also should point out how really outstanding our performance has been in the revenue cycle. And that's an important cost driver and we have been very effective in managing that, both from an expense and a cash flow perspective.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And you have your next question from the line of Kemp Dolliver from Avondale Partners.
componenttext: And you have your next question from the line of Kemp Dolliver from Avondale Partners.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Questions are on volumes. First, on your volume outlook for the year, it looks like you are expecting some improvement in the second half versus the first half, and just wanted to get your rationale behind that, given that Q1 likely had some weather disru
componenttext: Questions are on volumes. First, on your volume outlook for the year, it looks like you are expecting some improvement in the second half versus the first half, and just wanted to get your rationale behind that, given that Q1 likely had some weather disruption, which would lead one to think that Q2 would have shown better trends but they looked very similar in many regards, so that's what's behind my thought process.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to ask Biggs to speak to the outlook for volumes in the second half.
componenttext: I'm going to ask Biggs to speak to the outlook for volumes in the second half.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that you're right. We are expecting, if you're looking at it from a year-over-year trend standpoint, some improvement in the second half. It's our belief that our actions will drive volume, plus on the outpatient side, the acquisitions that we're
componenttext: I think that you're right. We are expecting, if you're looking at it from a year-over-year trend standpoint, some improvement in the second half. It's our belief that our actions will drive volume, plus on the outpatient side, the acquisitions that we're making that will fall under our hospital licenses will add volume on outpatient. But I think it's a moderate level of growth that's projected second half over first half from a trending standpoint. At a gross level, it may prove to be relatively flat for the first half because of seasonality. But from a year-over-year trending standpoint, yes, we're expecting some improvement as a result of our actions, be it physician recruitment, redirection, the outpatient acquisitions and everything else we're doing to drive volume. But it's a very modest amount of growth that we're expecting relative to the first half.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And also, several years ago, you all changed your admission criteria to eliminate a lot of short-term stays, and with the RAC Audits and I think other payer pressures, there appears to be intensified industry pressure, increasing observation stays, et cet
componenttext: And also, several years ago, you all changed your admission criteria to eliminate a lot of short-term stays, and with the RAC Audits and I think other payer pressures, there appears to be intensified industry pressure, increasing observation stays, et cetera. What are you seeing in terms of your very short stay cases as it relates to the Commercial book?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: As you point out, we made these changes several years ago, so weve really gone through anniversary dates already of the changes. The good news has been we've done really well on the RAC Audits. The bad news has been we probably depressed our admissions intentionally for some period of time. But that's really washed out before now.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: But no new pressures from there then.

componenttext: No, not to us. If we had not implemented those different criteria, which principally involved using the InterQual system, which is a method essentially of providing the same screening to admissions that the payers ultimately provide and that the RAC auditors are using. If we hadnt done that, probably would be in a position of seeing many admissions denied and overturned, and RAC Audits coming up with the big claims.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question on the operating cost side. I'm just trying to get some perspective on -- obviously, you've done a great job there over the last few years. If you could think over the last -- think back maybe three to five years ago what your ki
componenttext: Just a follow-up question on the operating cost side. I'm just trying to get some perspective on -- obviously, you've done a great job there over the last few years. If you could think over the last -- think back maybe three to five years ago what your kind of core and operating cost inflation trends look like, then compare it to where you are now, I'd be curious.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: That's a hard one.
componenttext: That's a hard one.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I can't remember what the inflationary trends were, but I can tell you that our cost management wasn't nearly as good. If you go back a few years, we were having volume losses. And we were staffing at levels that were too high for the volumes they were ex
componenttext: I can't remember what the inflationary trends were, but I can tell you that our cost management wasn't nearly as good. If you go back a few years, we were having volume losses. And we were staffing at levels that were too high for the volumes they were experiencing and constantly trying to chase that sort of after the fact and get our cost base right sized. But the processes we have in place now enable us to flex routinely on a daily basis. We have great tools in place and so that's not core inflation but certainly from the standpoint of our ability to manage cost growth, it is a big value driver.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess what I was trying to get to was obviously you've done -- The second question was just sort of a follow-up. I'm trying to get from a core perspective the -- what you've been able to drive yourself, which obviously have been a lot versus what you've
componenttext: I guess what I was trying to get to was obviously you've done -- The second question was just sort of a follow-up. I'm trying to get from a core perspective the -- what you've been able to drive yourself, which obviously have been a lot versus what you've kind of benefited from just on lower typical nursing inflation, things like that.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I see what you're saying. Look, we have really driven this improvement in productivity and this better performance on labor. The outside factors have been mixed on that. We've had pressures from labor unions. We've had continued competitive wage pressures
componenttext: I see what you're saying. Look, we have really driven this improvement in productivity and this better performance on labor. The outside factors have been mixed on that. We've had pressures from labor unions. We've had continued competitive wage pressures. And then, we had some benefit from lower turnover that was really caused in large part by the economy but also by a series of initiatives we undertook. So I guess if you want that sort of macro run own, I'd say there have been net probably neutral to slightly positive factors from the environment on labor, but huge positive factors from our own management techniques and the implementation of systems to manage that. On supplies, we've had sort of relentless upward pressure on the high-value supplies and fairly benign pricing pressure on commodity supplies. So once again, our efforts to manage utilization, to substitute and use equivalent but less expensive drugs and supplies and to be more conscious of the waste of supplies, the whole series of initiatives in the supply chain have really driven an outstanding performance there. And then I've mentioned revenue cycle earlier, and those, of course, are the huge drivers of cost.

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So you think these are replicable looking forward as the reimbursement environment gets tougher. I guess thats the real key.
componenttext: So you think these are replicable looking forward as the reimbursement environment gets tougher. I guess thats the real key.

componenttext: Well, I think independent of the reimbursement environment, as I said a few minutes ago, we continue to find new opportunities and new ways of being more efficient and saving money.

componenttext: I just want to go back to volume and just kind of reconciling the pre-announcement down 1.2% on the volume side then the quarter down 2% sort of implies that the last several weeks of the quarter obviously were down kind of 4% to 5%. And I know it's hard to sort of extrapolate just those last three weeks, but I guess first, is there nothing in those results that are meaningfully different other than just a sharper decline within admission trends across the board. And then, two, when you said that July remained soft, it is that in the context of the full 2Q results or the last three weeks of the quarter?

headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: The July was pretty consistent with the end of June. So it's softer than the second quarter but don't forget the really tough comps for last years July. So I think it's -- again, when you get into these really short-term periods where you're analyzing volumes, the prior year performance is important. The current year, if there's something from a service line perspective is important, and I think it's too limiting of a period to draw any broader conclusions than that, except just as a point of disclosure, we wanted to make sure we said, Look, we're off to a slow start for the third quarter on volume. As Biggs points out, we've taken into account in our outlook for the year that there's no dramatic recovery in volumes in the second half.

componenttext: And then, I just wanted to go back to managed care, I may have missed this. I know you gave sort of the percentages of the business that's locked in for the next couple, few years. headline: Tenet Healthcare Corp., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: With that, I think, I'll just proceed to make a couple of closing comments. This quarter, we took a decline of 2% admissions. We turned it into 3.3% growth in revenues and almost tripled that rate of growth in EBITDA. And we should be able to do a lot bet
componenttext: With that, I think, I'll just proceed to make a couple of closing comments. This quarter, we took a decline of 2% admissions. We turned it into 3.3% growth in revenues and almost tripled that rate of growth in EBITDA. And we should be able to do a lot better than that once we begin growing volumes again. We achieved new milestones in margins and free cash flows, and those are very important to keep in mind. We're taking excess cash and we're reducing debt. We're reducing the company's risk by extending maturities of our 2013 debt. And we plan to increase our flexibility by arranging a new credit line. During June and July, we engaged in an extensive amount of Investor Relations activity. We're going to resume this in September by attending the Morgan Stanley Conference and continuing to do one-on-one meeting in a few cities. And with that, operator, thank you. And this concludes our call.
